title: Chairs, chairs, everywhere, nor any place to sit
body:
The "real" Coleridge line doesn't sound nearly as good as the oft misquoted "water, water, everywhere, but not a drop to drink," but since I'm a Inglish Majer I thought I'd use the right one and risk sounding pretentious. I'm AWESOME!

At first, having an auditorium filled with vintage, low-back aluminum chairs sounded awesome - it was cool, it was retro, it was MOXIE - but now as they all slowly start to break, one-by-one, I'm wondering if we shouldn't upgrade to something newer. I should note, when I say "broken," I don't necessarily mean "impossible to sit in." The "broken" chairs I'm referring to are the ones that slope too far toward the ground when you're sitting in them (*cough* fourth row *cough*). Once the first batch of chairs broke (about 10 of them), my dad and uncle opened them up and welded new rings to the pivots, which seemed to solve the problem for the time being. However, I've since learned that "rings" and "pivots" were just terms used to describe the same thing: leprechauns.



As you can see, there are only two basic positions that a chair can be in at any one time. It's either up, or it's down... there is no in-between (despite the light shaded area between the two positions). Over time, the leprechaun that lives inside each chair grows old and dies, creating a broken chair. This is what a good chair looks like:



And this is what a bad chair looks like:



As you can clearly see, it all has to do with the health of each chair's particular leprechaun, which begs the question: if leprechauns can't be brought back from the dead, how can we fix our seats? Nicole posited the idea of welding folding legs onto the front of each chair, so as the bottom part extended outward into the sitting position, the legs would drop down and only allow the chair to drop to a comfortable degree. Unfortunately, this solution poses more problems than it solves - what if the legs don't fold back down when the seat pops back up? Would the little legs be strong enough to hold up the weight? And, most importantly, where would we find 150 little folding aluminum legs?

The more I think the problematic chairs, the more my head hurts. What do you guys suggest? If, however, you find yourself sitting in one of our esteemed broken chairs at a sold out Moxie show, just scoot your butt to the back of the seat. It works. Trust me.
author: Dan

comments.author: Derek
comments.body: I've never had a problem with the chairs. Most of the time when I go, the people (person) I'm with (*coughJonnacough*) mention(s) the chair issue and make(s) me trade since they "broken" chairs don't seem any different from any normal chair to me. Maybe it's the height that prevents me from knowing how a normal-sized chair should feel since all chairs feel small. Or maybe I'm just playing the role of martyr so people will think I'm cool. Okay, this comment is too long and I haven't given you any suggestions . . . Um, how about kicking complainers in the face like you always do, Dan? Nicole's idea is feasible, but the metal pieces plus hinges plus labor, etc. could end up being quite an expense. It's worth checking, though, right? Maybe.

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body:
I think you should just stop starving the leprechauns and FEED them once in a while. Even a popcorn kernel every now and then can expand their lives by 10 years or more.

Is there any way you could connect some super strong fabric straps to the back support part and the sides of the seat so that they are taut when the seat is in proper position? Does that make sense? I imagine it would be a lot cheaper than aluminum legs. The little straps might cause comfort issues on their own though.

OR since your 1-year is coming up, you could have a special deal where people can buy a new chair for the theater and get their name on it (which would stay on it for the life of the chair). Of course you would have to give the founding members their own chair still and pay for those new chairs yourself, but I bet you could sell all the rest of the seats easily. I imagine new chairs cost somewhere around $100-200 maybe? There are plenty of people/businesses in Springfield who would jump at a chance like that. Of course if they didn't jump, that would be a big expense to buy the chairs that didn't sell.
